I hear your company takes on capable fighters. I can handle myself in a scrap - interested?
You look useful. We pay fair coin for good work, and dead men don't collect. Fall in with the lads and keep your blade sharp.
Captain, I've been riding with the company long enough. Time we settled accounts.
You've earned your share and then some. Take your coin now and walk free, or stick around another year - I'll sweeten the pot. Your call.
I'll take my cut now. It's been good riding with you.
Coin's good, company's better. I'll stick around for that bonus.
Let me think on it. I'll find you when I've decided.
Fair winds, fighter. You've done right by the company. If you ever need work again, you know where to find us.
Smart choice. The lads will be glad to have you. Your bonus is guaranteed when the year's up. Now let's find some trouble.
Captain, the year's up. What's the score?
Another year done, and you're still breathing. Take your gold and go free, or sign on for another round - same deal as before. What'll it be?
I'll take my share. Time to see what else is out there.
The road's been good to me here. I'm in for another year.
Your coin's counted and your horse is yours. Good luck out there - and if you hear of any good contracts, send word.
Good man. The company's better for having you. Same terms, same coin - let's get back to work.
I've had my rest. Ready to get back to work, captain.
Good timing. We've got work lined up and could use another blade. Fall in with the lads.
Captain, I need to break contract early. Something's come up.
Contract's done then. No hard feelings - everyone's got their reasons. Don't expect a warm welcome if you come crawling back soon, though.
Your {UNIT_NAME} has served you well these many months. What of your men? They may return to the ranks, or... if they wish to follow you into the unknown, I shall not stop them.
My men have chosen to march with me, my lord. We've bled together - that bond does not break so easily.
Let them return to the army. They signed on to serve the kingdom, not one man.
So be it. Your {COUNT} soldiers have decided to stay with you rather than re-enlist. I've had the quartermaster set aside provisions for your journey. Fare well, soldier.
Your lads have been asking around. Word is they'd rather follow you than draw army pay. Your call, fighter.
Tell them to pack their gear. We ride together.
They're good fighters. The company needs them more than I do.
Ha! Loyal to the end, that lot. Your {COUNT} have decided to stay with you instead of signing back on. Here's some grain for the road - you'll need it. Don't be a stranger.

After the Battle

The battle is won. As your men regroup, you notice soldiers from other units looking your way. Your reputation precedes you, Commander.\n\nA corporal approaches. "Sir, some of the lads want to join your retinue. What should I tell them?"
"Volunteers step forward."
Fresh faces join your ranks. They look to you with respect.
"Request formal transfers from the captain."
The captain scowls but complies. More soldiers report for duty, though your lord may not appreciate the request.
"We have enough. Tell them to return to their units."
Your men appreciate that you will not over-extend. They know you value quality over numbers.
Recognition in the Ranks

Word of your recent victory has spread through the camp. Your retinue's performance in battle has not gone unnoticed.\n\n{LORD_NAME} approaches you after the evening meal. "Your men fought well, Commander. The army could use more leaders like you."
"The credit belongs to the men, my lord."
Your lord nods approvingly. The soldiers nearby exchange pleased glances - their commander remembers who does the fighting.
"I trained them well, my lord."
"Confidence is good in a commander," your lord replies. "I shall remember this."
"With more men, I could do even better, my lord."
Your lord's eyes narrow slightly, but he nods. "Very well. I shall assign a few more to your command." You may have pushed too hard.

You step back without making your request. Better to wait for a more opportune moment.
Write a Letter Home
You have a moment of quiet. Perhaps it's time to send word home - to family, friends, or whoever waits for your return. Ink and parchment aren't hard to come by.
Write a reassuring letter, downplaying the dangers.
You craft a letter full of small triumphs and omitted hardships. It feels good to write, to remember there's a world beyond war. You hand it to the camp courier.
Write an honest account of your experiences.
The words flow more freely than expected. It's cathartic to put the truth on paper, even if it might worry those who read it.
I'll write when I have more to say.
You set aside the parchment. The words aren't coming today.
Call in a Quartermaster Favor
The quartermaster owes you one. You could call in that favor to ease the pressure - or keep it for later.
Call it in: smooth things over and keep the company steady.
A quiet word, a quiet exchange. The wagons run smoother for a while, and the men complain a little less. The quartermaster's favor is spent.
Hold it: I'll save that favor for a worse day.
You keep the favor in your pocket. In this life, leverage is a kind of coin.
Invitation to Hunt
{LORD_NAME} is organizing a hunting party. A messenger approaches you with an invitation. The Lord's hunts are known for good sport and fine company - though they can be tiring affairs.
"I am honored, my Lord. I shall attend."
You spend the day riding with {LORD_NAME}'s party. The hunt is successful - deer are brought down, and the mood is jovial. As the party returns, {LORD_NAME} offers you your share.
"I am grateful for the honor, but duty keeps me at camp."
The messenger nods and departs. Perhaps another time.
Evening Dice Game
{COMRADE_NAME} waves you over to a group gathered around a small fire. "Come on, {PLAYER_RANK}! We need fresh gold in the pot." The dice game looks lively, and you could use some relaxation.
"Deal me in - small stakes only."
Lady luck favors you tonight. You walk away with your stake doubled and a few new friends.
"I'm feeling lucky. High stakes."
The dice fly, the gold flows. You take the pot with a winning streak that has the whole camp talking.
"Not tonight. I need my rest."
You retire to your tent. The sounds of laughter and curses drift through the night.
Training Opportunity

{SERGEANT_NAME} approaches during training. "You show promise, soldier. I could work with you after the regular session - push you harder than the rest. It'll be exhausting, but you'll improve faster."
"I'm ready for whatever you can teach me, Sergeant."
The additional training is brutal, but effective. Your muscles ache, but your blade moves faster.
"I appreciate the offer, but I need to pace myself."
{SERGEANT_NAME} shrugs. "Your choice. The offer stands." You continue with the standard regimen.
Special Scouting Assignment
{SERGEANT_NAME} pulls you aside. "I need someone reliable for a longer patrol. Two days out, mapping the terrain ahead. It's harder work, but I'll make sure you're compensated."
"Consider it done. I'll have a full report for you."
You ride out at dawn and return two days later with detailed reports. {SERGEANT_NAME} nods with approval and hands you a pouch of coins.
"I'm not in condition for extended patrol right now."
{SERGEANT_NAME} frowns slightly but accepts your answer. Someone else will take the assignment.
Medical Emergency
A commotion breaks out near the medical tent. One of the wounded has taken a turn for the worse - fever and infection. The other medics look to you. "What do we do? The surgeon isn't here!"
"Get me clean water and fresh bandages. I'll handle this."
You work through the night, applying poultices and monitoring the soldier's condition. By dawn, the fever breaks. Word spreads of your skill.
"We need the surgeon. Someone ride to find him - I'll stabilize the patient."
You keep the soldier stable until the surgeon arrives. A prudent choice - the surgeon handles the complication expertly.
Merchant's Proposition

A traveling merchant approaches with a wagon of surplus goods. "I've got quality supplies here - arrows, blankets, preserved meat. I can give you a good price, but I need to move quickly. The captain doesn't need to know the details..."
"I'll need to clear any purchase through proper channels."
The merchant grumbles but agrees to wait. You get authorization, and the company gains quality supplies through legitimate means.
"Show me what you've got. We can work something out."
You skim a little off the top while getting the company a good deal. Risky, but profitable.
"Something seems off here. I should report this."
You alert the captain. The merchant's goods turn out to be stolen from a nearby village. Your vigilance is noted.
Supply Run
The wagons are light and the men are counting days between towns. You can make a run to secure supplies — properly, quietly, or harshly.
Do it properly: pay a fair price, record it cleanly.
You spend coin and time, but the wagons come back heavier and the ledger stays clean. The quartermaster gives you a rare, approving nod.
Make it work: buy cheap, skim a little, keep everyone fed.
You get the supplies. You also get paid. For now, nobody asks how the numbers work out.
Ration hard: stretch what we have and keep the wagons moving.
You tighten belts and enforce rationing. The men grumble, but the supplies last longer.
Audit Pressure
A clerk is sniffing around the ledgers, asking careful questions. If anything is wrong, they'll find it. You can face it, bury it, or buy time.
Cooperate: fix what you can and take the hit.
You swallow pride and clean up the mess. It costs you standing, but the investigation cools — for now.
Burn the paper trail: make the problem disappear.
The ledger pages curl to ash. The questions stop. But you've crossed a line that doesn't uncross.
Buy time: pay a quiet bribe and keep things moving.
Coin changes hands. The clerk loses interest. You gain a few weeks of breathing room.
A Favor Asked

{COMRADE_NAME} pulls you aside with a troubled look. "I need to ask a favor. My family... they've fallen behind on their debts. I need coin, and quickly. Could you lend me something? I swear I'll repay you when I can."
"Take what you need, friend. We look after our own."
{COMRADE_NAME}'s face floods with relief. "You're a good soldier, {PLAYER_NAME}. I won't forget this." He takes the coin and hurries off to send it to his family.
"I can spare a little. It's not much, but take it."
{COMRADE_NAME} nods gratefully. "Every bit helps. Thank you, {PLAYER_NAME}." He pockets the coins with a small smile.
"I can't afford to give away my coin. I'm sorry."
{COMRADE_NAME}'s expression hardens slightly, but he nods. "I understand. Times are hard for everyone." He walks away without another word.
A Debt Repaid

{COMRADE_NAME} approaches with a grin and a pouch of coins. "I told you I'd repay you, didn't I? My sister sold some of the family land - we're back on our feet. Here's what I owe, and a little extra for your trust."
"I'm glad things worked out. Thank you."
You pocket the coins with a nod. {COMRADE_NAME} claps you on the shoulder. "If you ever need anything, just ask." A bond has been strengthened.
"Keep it. Consider it a gift between comrades."
{COMRADE_NAME} stares at you in surprise, then breaks into a broad smile. "You're one of the good ones, {PLAYER_NAME}. I'll remember this." Your reputation in the company soars.
A Small Thanks
{COMRADE_NAME} finds you during a rest break and hands you a small bundle. "It's not much, but I found this while foraging. Thought you might want it, after what you did for me."
"Thank you. It means a lot."
You unwrap the bundle to find a few useful supplies. Small gestures, but they build trust within the company.
"Keep it. You don't owe me anything."
{COMRADE_NAME} insists once, then nods, embarrassed but grateful. "Still... thank you." The gesture seems to matter more than the coin.
Your legs ache from the march and your eyes burn from too many watches. A soldier learns to grab sleep wherever he can find it.
Find a shady spot and steal what rest you can.
You wedge yourself between supply crates, cloak bundled as a pillow. The camp noise fades. When you stir, the shadows have moved but you feel lighter.
Rest near the fire with the other soldiers.
You doze at the fire's edge, half-listening to the men's talk. Not deep sleep, but the company keeps the darker thoughts at bay.
Push through. Sleep is for the garrison.
You shake off the weariness. The campaign waits for no man's comfort.
Extended Rest
You need real sleep, not just a nap. A full night's rest would do wonders, but you'd be unavailable for a while.
Find your bedroll and get proper sleep.
You sleep deeply and wake feeling like a new man. Your body thanks you for the rest.
I can sleep when I'm dead.
You push through the exhaustion. Sleep can wait.
Seek Treatment
The surgeon's tent. Time to deal with your wounds properly. It'll cost coin, but proper care prevents worse problems.
Pay for proper treatment. (30 gold)
The surgeon cleans and binds your wounds with practiced hands. It stings like hell, but you'll heal clean.
Just the basics - bandages and salve. (10 gold)
Basic supplies change hands. It's not fancy, but it helps.
I'll manage on my own.
You leave the surgeon's tent. Time and luck will have to do the work.
Weapon Drill
Practice forms with the training posts. Basic work, but it builds muscle memory.
Work through the basic forms.
Swing, block, thrust, recover. You run through the forms until your arms burn. It's honest work.
Not now.
The training posts will be there tomorrow.
Sparring Match
The drill ground is busy. A few soldiers are working through forms, but the real learning happens when blades cross. {SOLDIER_NAME} catches your eye and tilts his head toward the practice ring.
Accept the invitation. Keep it friendly.
Wooden blades crack together as you circle, testing each other's guards. Neither of you holds back, but nobody's trying to prove anything. You're both better for it.
Make it count. Fight like you mean it.

This one draws blood. You go at each other like there's a real grudge, and the watching soldiers fall quiet. When it's done, you're both breathing hard and sporting fresh bruises. Word will spread about this bout.
Not today. Shake your head and move on.
{SOLDIER_NAME} shrugs and finds another partner. No shame in knowing when to save your strength.
Endurance Training
Run the camp perimeter until your lungs burn. Soldiers live and die by their stamina.
Run laps around the camp.
You run until your chest heaves and your legs scream for mercy. Each lap makes you harder to kill.
Save my energy.
You decide to conserve your strength for when it matters.
Study Tactics
Borrow a map, think about formations. Wars are won by those who think before they fight.
Study the maps and think about what you've seen.
You pore over old battle maps, considering terrain, formation, and timing. The patterns of war become clearer.
Maps can wait.
You set aside the scrolls. Practice beats theory anyway.
Practice Medicine
Offer to help the surgeon with simple cases. Field medicine isn't pretty, but it saves lives.
Help the surgeon with patients.
You spend hours helping with wounds and illnesses. The surgeon grunts approval at your work. The patients appreciate a steady hand.
Not today.
The surgeon has other helpers. Your hands stay clean.
Train the Men
Take recruits through drills. They'll learn from your experience - assuming you don't break them first.
Take charge of training drills.
You put the recruits through their paces. They curse your name, but they'll fight better for it. The officers nod approvingly.
Let someone else handle it.
Training is someone else's responsibility today.
Combat Drill
Request extra drill time with the sergeant. Hard work, but it sharpens your equipped weapon skills.
Practice with your equipped weapon.
The sergeant works you hard, focusing on the weapon you carry. Your movements become more fluid, more deadly.
Maybe later.
The drill grounds can wait.
Weapon Specialization
Focus your training on the weapon you use most. Specialists kill faster than generalists.
Focus on mastering your main weapon.
Hours of focused practice. Your hands know this weapon like an extension of your body now.
I prefer variety.
Specialization can wait. Flexibility has its merits.
Lead Drill Practice
Lead drill practice for younger soldiers. Teaching reinforces your own skills while building your reputation.
Take charge of junior soldiers' training.
You command the drill with authority. The young soldiers respond to your orders crisply. Officers watching from the sidelines look impressed.
Let the sergeants handle it.
Training others isn't your job today.
Join the Men
Sit by their fire, share stories. Good for morale - theirs and yours.
Sit with the soldiers at their fire.
You share warmth and stories with your comrades. They appreciate an equal. The officers might not approve, but camaraderie is earned, not assigned.
Keep my distance.
You stay apart. Sometimes a soldier needs his own company.
Join the Drinking
Someone's opened a cask. Join in? Drinking builds bonds but attracts attention.
Have a few drinks with the lads.
You share drink and laughter. The night blurs pleasantly. Tomorrow's headache will be worth tonight's camaraderie.
Drink deep and let the night take you.
You drink until the stars spin. They'll talk about this night. Whether that's good or bad remains to be seen.
I'll pass.
You decline the drink. Clear heads have their value.
Seek the Officers
Linger near the command tent, look useful. Ambition requires visibility.
Make yourself visible to the officers.
You find reasons to be near the command tent. The officers notice. The men notice too - and they don't always approve of climbers.
Stay with my own rank.
You stay with the men. Advancement can come naturally.
Keep to Yourself
Sometimes solitude is worth more than company. Find a quiet spot away from the crowd.
Find somewhere quiet and be alone.
You find a quiet corner of camp and let your thoughts settle. The silence is a relief after the constant noise of military life.
Maybe I should be social.
You reconsider. The company of others has its merits.
Write a Letter Home
Ink, paper, and memories of another life. Someone back home might appreciate hearing from you.
Write a reassuring letter, downplaying the dangers.
You craft careful words of safety and good fortune. No need to worry those waiting for you. The courier takes your letter with the next dispatch.
Write honestly about your experiences.
The truth flows onto the page - the fear, the boredom, the moments of strange pride. It feels good to be honest, even if the words might worry them.
The words won't come today.
You set aside the paper. Another time.
Confront Your Rival
This has gone on long enough. There's someone in camp who's been making your life difficult. Time to settle it.
Confront them directly, with words.
You find your rival and say what needs saying. The tension breaks - for better or worse, the air is cleared.
Settle it with fists, away from officers.
You trade blows behind the supply wagons. Win or lose, it's done. The men respect those who handle their problems directly.
Let it go, for now.
You swallow your anger. Some battles aren't worth fighting.
Gamble (Low Stakes)
Behind the supply wagons, a circle of soldiers hunches over a blanket. Dice clatter, coins change hands. Someone spots you watching and waves you over. 'Room for one more, if your coin's good.'
Toss in your copper and play for laughs. (10 gold stake)
The bones love you tonight. You sweep a modest pot toward yourself while the others groan and call for another round. Easy money, easy company.
The dice turn cold. Your stake vanishes into other purses, but you share the groans and laughter with the rest. Cost of camaraderie.
Play carefully. Watch the odds. (10 gold stake)
You play tight, fold when the odds turn, push when they favor you. The pot's smaller, but it's yours. The others eye you with something between respect and annoyance.
Even careful play can't beat a cold run. You walk away lighter, but at least you didn't chase your losses.
'Not tonight, lads.' Keep walking.
You wave them off and move on. Your purse stays full, but you miss the camaraderie of the circle.
Gamble (High Stakes)
Real money. Real risk. The kind of game where fortunes change hands.
Put real money on the table. (50 gold stake)
Fortune favors the bold! You rake in a substantial pot. The losers eye you with new respect - or jealousy.
The dice betray you. Your stake is gone, and then some. The winners smirk as you count what's left.
Too rich for my blood.
You keep your gold in your purse. Wisdom, or cowardice? Only you know.
Side Work
Someone in camp needs labor. Pays decent - if you don't mind the sweat.
Put in extra labor for coin.
Hours of hard labor - hauling, digging, lifting. Your back aches, but your purse is heavier.
My duty is enough.
You pass on the extra work. Rest has value too.
Shady Deal
A man knows a man who has something to sell. The goods look legitimate enough, but the price is suspiciously low.
Make the deal. Don't ask questions.
Coin changes hands in shadows. You don't know where the goods came from, and you don't ask. Profit is profit.
Report the suspicious offer.
You tell the officers about the offer. They nod approvingly. The shady man disappears before anyone can question him.
Walk away.
You want no part of whatever this is. Clean hands are worth more than dirty coin.
Visit the Market
Browse what the town has to offer. Supplies, luxuries, maybe something useful.
Spend some time browsing the stalls.
You wander the market, examining wares. The variety is a pleasant change from camp rations and military issue.
No time for shopping.
Duty calls louder than commerce.
Request an Audience

The lord's banner hangs above the command tent. Guards stand watch, and officers come and go on important business. A common soldier doesn't just walk in�but your rank has earned you the right to petition, if you've something worth saying.
Remind the lord of your service. Speak of what you've done.
{LORD_NAME} hears you out, eyes sharp. When you finish, there's a pause�then a single nod. 'I know your face now, soldier. Continue to serve well.' It's not much, but from a lord, it's everything.
Humbly request an advance on wages. Debts press hard.

You explain your circumstances as briefly as you can. The lord's expression is unreadable, but he gestures to his steward. A purse of coins lands in your palm. 'See that it's repaid in service.' You're in debt now�of a different kind.
Ask for the chance to prove yourself in some special task.

The lord's eyebrow rises. Ambition, or foolishness? 'I'll remember your eagerness, soldier. When something needs doing, perhaps I'll send for you.' You've put your name forward. Now you must prove worthy of it.
Lose your nerve. This isn't the time.
You hover at the tent's edge, then turn away. The guards don't even glance at you. Better to wait for a stronger hand to play.
Volunteer for Duty
Tell the sergeant you want extra work. Initiative is noticed - for better or worse.
Volunteer for additional duties.
{NCO_NAME} nods at your offer. Extra work finds you quickly. The officers appreciate initiative. Some of the men think you're showing off.
My regular duties are enough.
You stay quiet. No need to stand out more than necessary.
Request Leave
Ask permission to visit town on your own time. Officers don't always approve, but it doesn't hurt to ask.
Request permission for leave.
Permission granted, with conditions. You have until evening. Don't make them regret it.
Request denied. The officer barely looks up. 'We march soon. Stay with the company.'
Never mind.
You decide not to ask. There will be other opportunities.
Listen to Rumors
Keep your ears open around camp. Information is currency in any army.
Drift through camp, listening to talk.
You catch fragments of conversation - troop movements, noble politics, fears and hopes. Some of it might even be true.
Rumors are for bored soldiers.
You have better things to do than gossip.
Scout the Surroundings
Take a walk beyond the camp perimeter. Know the land - it might save your life.
Walk the perimeter and beyond.
You explore the terrain around camp - paths, hiding spots, approaches. Knowledge that might matter when swords are drawn.
Stay inside the perimeter.
The camp is safe enough. No need to wander.
Check Supply Situation
Ask the quartermaster how we're doing. Good to know before things get desperate.
Inquire about the company's supplies.
The quartermaster shares the state of things - food stores, fodder, equipment. Information is power, even in small matters.
I'll find out when everyone else does.
Ignorance has its comforts. You'll know when you need to know.
Maintain Your Gear
Oil, polish, sharpen. Keep it battle-ready. A soldier's gear is his life.
Spend time maintaining your equipment.
You work methodically - cleaning rust, sharpening edges, oiling leather. Your gear is ready for whatever comes.
Good enough for now.
Your gear will survive another day. Probably.
Visit the Quartermaster
See what's available, maybe make a request. The quartermaster has what you need - for a price.
See what the quartermaster has in stock.
You browse the quartermaster's stores. Weapons, armor, supplies - all available for coin or requisition. Good to know what's possible.
I have what I need.
Your current kit will serve. No need to spend coin you don't have.
Accept a Dangerous Wager

The men are getting creative with boredom. {SOLDIER_NAME} grins at you across the fire. 'Heard you've got brass ones. Bet you twenty denars you can't...' What follows is either incredibly dangerous or incredibly stupid. Possibly both.
'You're on.' Stand up and prove it.

Your heart pounds, the men roar, and somehow�you pull it off. {SOLDIER_NAME}'s coins land in your palm while the camp erupts. They'll be telling this story for weeks. You'll be feeling it for just as long.

Pride goes before the fall. You hit the ground hard, or burn yourself, or whatever fool thing you were attempting goes wrong. The men wince. The coin goes to {SOLDIER_NAME}. Your pride goes to the mud.
'Double or nothing�but on my terms.'
You turn the challenge around, stack the odds your way. It's still risky, but calculated. When you succeed, the winnings are sweeter�and you barely limp afterward.
Even the clever approach goes wrong sometimes. You're out more coin and nursing new bruises. At least you tried to be smart about it.
'I've nothing to prove to you.' Stay seated.
You shake your head. {SOLDIER_NAME} shrugs, calls you sensible or coward depending on the drink in him. Tomorrow, nobody will remember you turned it down. Or maybe they will.
Prove Your Courage
Do something reckless to earn respect. The men respect courage - even the foolish kind.
Do something bold and reckless.
You do something brave and stupid. The men cheer. The officers groan. Your body pays the price, but your reputation doesn't.
Courage can wait.
You decide against showboating. Real courage shows in battle, not in camp stunts.
Challenge Someone
Call them out. Settle it properly, with witnesses. The old ways still matter.
Issue a formal challenge.
Steel rings, blood flows. Win or lose, you've made a statement. The officers will hear about this - as will everyone else.
Some insults aren't worth dying for.
You let it pass. The smart choice, if not the satisfying one.
Inspect Your Retinue
Walk the line. Check gear, check morale, check readiness. Your men need to see you care about their condition.
Conduct a thorough inspection. Check every soldier personally.
You walk the line slowly, speaking to each man. You notice worn straps, dull blades, blisters that need tending. They see you noticing. That matters.
Quick pass. Show your face, keep it moving.
A brisk walk down the line. They straighten as you pass. It's not much, but it shows you haven't forgotten them.
They're fine without my supervision.
Your men can handle themselves. No need to hover.
Drill Your Soldiers
Run your men through combat drills. Hard work builds discipline and readiness, but push too hard and morale suffers.
Push them hard. No mercy, no excuses.
You drive them until they curse your name. Shield walls crash, formations wheel, weapons sing. They hate it now, but they'll thank you when steel crosses steel.
Firm but fair. Work them, but don't break them.
You push them through the forms with a firm hand and an occasional word of encouragement. They sweat, they learn, they respect the work.
Keep it light. Build confidence, not exhaustion.
You run them through basic drills without breaking a sweat. They appreciate the easy day. Whether that makes them better soldiers is another question.
They've drilled enough.
Training can wait. Rest is part of readiness too.
Share Your Rations
Your men are on standard field rations. You have better food in your personal stores. Sharing builds loyalty, but costs coin to replace.
Break out the good stuff. Make it a proper meal. (50 gold)
You share meat, bread, and even a skin of wine. Your men feast like officers for one night. They won't forget this.
Share what you can spare. Simple generosity. (20 gold)
You hand out dried meat and cheese from your personal stores. It's not a feast, but the gesture matters.
They're paid soldiers. They can buy their own food.
You keep your stores to yourself. They get what they're issued, like everyone else.
Address Your Men
Your soldiers are assembled. Time to speak to them as their commander. What you say now will set the tone of your leadership.
Speak of honor, duty, and shared glory.
You speak from the heart. Words about brotherhood, courage, and the battles to come. Some men stand straighter. A few even look inspired.
Set clear expectations. Demand excellence.
You lay out standards and consequences. No room for weakness, no tolerance for failure. They understand what's expected.
Keep it brief and practical. We have work to do.
You keep it short. No grand speeches, no theatrics. Just a commander talking to soldiers. They appreciate not wasting time.
Actions speak louder than words.
You decide to let your deeds speak for you. The men disperse without ceremony.
The battlefield is the only home I know, my lord. I shall stay and earn that gold.
I thank you for everything, my lord. It has been an honor to serve under your banner.
You have my oath, my lord. Point me at the enemy.
Ha! That's the spirit! I knew I could count on you. Another year, then. Try not to get yourself killed.
Why would I leave now? We have enemies yet to crush. Count me in for another year.
Your offer is generous, my lord, but I must think on it. Perhaps another time.

Hold a moment... I recognize your bearing. You serve another lord, do you not? A soldier cannot serve two masters. Return to your commander, or settle your affairs with them first before approaching me.
My lord, I seek to speak with you about bearing arms in your service.
If you wish to leave my service, do it properly. Make camp and request discharge. Your final pay and discharge papers will be handled at the next muster.
My lord, if I wished to leave your service, how would I do so properly?
My lord, I have served faithfully these many months. The time has come to discuss my future.
My lord, I must ask to be released from my oath. I cannot continue.
I release you from your oath. You leave without the honors of a full term, but you are free. Go, and think carefully before you take up arms again.
You have been discharged from service without full benefits.
I see the steel in your eyes. You'll do. But know this - I expect loyalty, discipline, and courage. Here are my terms...
A soldier who seeks a new banner rather than deserting? That speaks well of your character. I welcome you to my company. These are my terms...
Speak freely. What brings a warrior to my hall?
Ha! I knew you had more fight in you. Your gold will be waiting when the year is done. Now get back to your post.
My lord, you may remember me - I served this realm before. The quiet life does not suit me. Will you have me back?
My lord, another year has passed. What becomes of me now?
It is time I sought my own path, my lord. I thank you for the opportunity.
Then this is farewell, for now. You have been a fine soldier. May the winds carry you to fortune.
You have proven yourself time and again. Take your discharge with five thousand gold and my blessing, or stay another year with a bonus to match. What say you?
I offer you my sword and my loyalty, my lord. Will you have me in your ranks?
My lord, fate has taken my commander from me. I am a soldier without a banner, but my oath to this kingdom remains. Will you take me under your command?
My lord, I currently serve another of this realm, but I believe my talents would be better suited under your banner. Would you accept my transfer?

You have served with honor, and I do not forget loyalty. Retire now and you leave with gold in your pocket, my personal letter of recommendation, and the respect of this kingdom. Or... stay another year, and I shall double your severance. The choice is yours.
Go well, soldier. You have earned your peace. Should you ever wish to return, my door remains open.
This is not a decision to make lightly. Give me time to consider, my lord.
Good to see you standing tall again. The men will be glad to have you back. Fall in with your company.
I have rested enough, my lord. My blade grows restless. I am ready to return to the front.
You have returned to active military service.
Forgive me, my lord. I spoke out of turn. I have nothing to discuss at this time.

You will march when I say march, fight when I say fight, and hold the line when all seems lost. Your term is three years. In return, you shall have daily wages and a place by the fire. Do we have an accord?
A soldier who knows his worth. Very well, I shall send word to your former commander. From this day, you march with me.
You have transferred your service to {LORD_NAME}. Your rank and experience have been preserved.
My sword arm is strong as ever, my lord. Where do you need me?
Good to have you back in the ranks. Report to the Master at Arms to choose your role, then find your company.
Forgive me, my lord. The call to arms is strong, but I am not yet ready. Perhaps another day.
I remember you! A good soldier returns to the fold. Your old rank awaits, though you will need to choose your specialty anew. Serve one year and you leave with gold in hand.
It's a long story. Let's just say I ended up here after some... interesting experiences.
Let me see what I've got in stock for you.
[Quartermaster responds to sell request]
Mostly dented helms and rusty blades today.
Mixed lot. Some worn, some decent.
Some quality pieces came in with the last wagon.
Out of stock. Check back after the next muster.
Choose Your Retinue
What type of soldiers will you command?
Foot soldiers with sword and shield
Skilled bowmen for ranged support
Mounted lancers, swift and deadly
Horse Archers
Mounted bowmen of the steppe
You have chosen to command {FORMATION}. Your recruits will reflect this choice.
Discontent in the Ranks
Your men have grown restless. You hear grumbling during the evening meal, and discipline is slipping. Something needs to be done before morale deteriorates further.
Gather the men. We need to talk.
They will obey or face consequences.
They will settle down on their own.
You gather your men and hear their grievances. With a few small gestures and promises, spirits lift. Your soldiers know you care about their wellbeing.
You crack down hard. The grumbling stops, but your men obey out of fear rather than respect. Officers take notice of the harsh methods.
You do nothing. The discontent festers. Your soldiers notice your indifference, and morale sinks further.
Desertion Risk
Your corporal approaches with grave news. 'Commander, the men are talking about deserting. They say you have failed them. If you do not act now, we will lose soldiers.'
I will pay them from my own purse.
I will remind them why they follow me.
If they wish to leave, let them.
You distribute coin to your soldiers. They are surprised and grateful. Word spreads that you value their service enough to pay from your own pocket.
You address your men with passion and conviction. Your words stir their hearts. They remember why they chose to follow you into battle.
You try to rally your men, but your words ring hollow. You lack the presence to truly inspire them. Still, some appreciate the effort.
Three of your soldiers desert in the night. The remaining men are shaken but realize you will not beg them to stay.
On the Brink of Mutiny
Your retinue is in crisis. Men refuse orders. Some have drawn weapons. Your corporal warns you: 'Commander, they are ready to mutiny. You must act NOW or we lose everything.'
Pay them triple wages. Whatever it takes.
I will appeal to our lord for assistance.
Dismiss the troublemakers and rebuild.
I will not negotiate with mutineers.
You empty your purse. Your soldiers are stunned by the gesture. The crisis passes. They will follow you again, though trust must still be rebuilt.
Your lord intervenes, addressing your men personally. The crisis is averted, but your lord now questions your ability to command.
You dismiss the ringleaders without mercy. Five men are sent away. The remaining soldiers see you will tolerate no insubordination.
You stand your ground. Eight soldiers desert in the night. Those who remain are loyal, but your retinue is crippled.
Devoted Soldiers
Your retinue gathers around the campfire after evening muster. One of your veterans stands. 'Commander, we wanted you to know: we would follow you to the gates of hell. You have our loyalty.'
I am honored to lead such men.
Then let us celebrate. Drinks are on me.
Good. Then you are ready for harder training.
Your soldiers nod in respect. The bond between you and your men grows stronger. They would die for you without hesitation.
You buy a round for your soldiers. Laughter and song fill the camp. Your men are grateful to serve under a commander who values them.
Your soldiers grin at the challenge. They trust you to make them better warriors. Training begins at dawn.
Trouble in the Ranks

Shouting draws you to the fire pit. Two of your soldiers are at each other's throats - one has the other by the collar.

'He cheated at dice!' one shouts. 'I'll kill him!'

Your men watch, waiting to see what their commander does.
Both of you. Extra watch duty. Tonight. Now get out of my sight.
Neither man is happy, but they separate. Order is maintained. Your officers approve of the swift discipline.
What happened? You first. Then you.
You listen. Turns out it was a misunderstanding. You make them shake hands. The men respect that you bothered to hear them out.
Settle it. Fists only. First blood ends it.
Fists fly. It's over quickly. Both men shake hands afterward, the matter settled the old way.
The fight gets out of hand. One man takes a bad hit and is down. You call for the surgeon.
Handle it yourselves. I have better things to do.
You walk away. The men exchange looks. Their commander does not care. The tension will fester.
A Soldier's Plea

One of your soldiers approaches, cap in hand. He's been reliable - never shirks, never complains.\n\n'Commander... my wife sent word. The baby's coming. I know the timing's poor, but... please. Let me go to her. Just for a week.'
Go. Family comes first. Be back in seven days.
The man's face lights up. He grabs your hand, thanking you over and over. The other soldiers see this. They know you are not heartless.
I am sorry. We may see battle any day. I cannot spare you.
His face falls. He nods slowly, knowing your words are true but hating you for them. The men mutter among themselves. Some things matter more than war.
You cannot go. But take this gold and send a fast rider with gifts for your wife.
He hesitates, then accepts the coin. It's not what he wanted, but it's something. The men see you tried to help. That counts for something.
Missing Rations

Your corporal reports a problem: rations have gone missing from the supply cart. Half a week's bread and salt meat, vanished in the night.\n\n'Could be one of ours, Commander. Could be camp followers. What do you want to do?'
Question everyone. Search the tents. I want answers.
After hours of questioning, you find the culprit - a soldier feeding a starving family in the village. You recover what remains. The men see you are thorough but fair.
Half rations for everyone until the thief confesses.
Hunger breeds resentment. By nightfall, the men drag the thief before you. The rations are found. But now everyone is angry - at you as much as the thief.
Buy replacement rations from my own coin. Let it go.
You pay for new supplies without fuss. The men appreciate that you didn't make a scene. The thief, whoever they are, owes you.
We will manage. Forget about it.
You let it slide. A week later, more rations vanish. Then some coin. Weakness invites predators. Even your own men start taking liberties.
The Old Hand

Your oldest soldier pulls you aside after the morning briefing. He's fought in more wars than you've seen winters.\n\n'Commander... that order you gave. About the patrol route. With respect, it's a bad call. I've seen men die going that way. The ravine bottlenecks. Perfect for ambush.'
You know these lands better than I do. What do you suggest?
The veteran lays out an alternative. It's better - you can see that immediately. You change the orders. The men notice their commander listens. That matters.
I have my reasons. The order stands.
The veteran's jaw tightens. 'As you say, Commander.' He walks off. The order stands. You hope you're right - because if you're wrong, men will die.
Send scouts ahead. If the ravine is clear, we proceed as planned.
The veteran nods. 'Fair enough, Commander. At least you're thinking.' The scouts report back - he was right. You adjust the plan. Everyone saves face.
Raw Meat

Three new soldiers report for duty, fresh from the training grounds. They look around nervously, still soft, still scared. Your veterans eye them with a mixture of amusement and contempt.\n\nHow do you welcome them to your retinue?
War is not what the songs say. You will learn or you will die. Fall in.
The recruits pale. Good. Fear keeps men alive. Your veterans nod approvingly - you don't coddle greenhorns. These three will learn fast or die trying.
Welcome to the company. Stay close to the veterans - they will keep you alive.
The recruits relax slightly. One of your veterans claps the nearest on the shoulder. 'Don't worry, lad. Commander's decent. Just do what you're told.' Integration begins.
Show me what you can do. Draw your weapons. Now.
You run them through drills. Two are clumsy but eager. One shows promise. You assign each to a veteran mentor. They'll learn the company's ways soon enough.

Your lord calls you to his tent. His expression is grim.

'I need your retinue to hold the rear while the army withdraws. It's a dangerous position - there will be casualties. But someone must buy us time.'

He doesn't say it, but you know: your men are the expendable ones.
As you command, my lord. We will hold.
Your lord nods approvingly. Your men hold the line. Some fall, but the army escapes. Your lord remembers your sacrifice. Your soldiers remember being sacrificed.
We will hold, my lord - but I want reinforcements to cover our withdrawal.
Your lord hesitates, then agrees. You get a handful of archers for cover. Your men see you negotiated for their lives. They appreciate the effort.
My men are not fodder, my lord. Find another way.
Your lord's face hardens. 'Remember who commands here.' He finds another unit for the task. Your men love you for standing up for them. Your lord will not forget this defiance.

Your men are tired, hungry, and fed up. They don't say it to your face, but you hear them muttering around the cookfires. Morale is dangerously low.\n\nSomething must be done before discontent turns to desertion.
Break out the good wine. Tonight, we feast.
You break open your personal stores. Wine flows, stories are told, laughter returns. Your men see you share their hardship. That means more than any speech.
Gather round. We need to talk about why we fight.
You speak of duty, of honor, of the bonds forged in battle. Some men are moved. Others remain skeptical. Words alone cannot fill empty bellies, but they help.
I will not tolerate grumbling. The next man who complains pulls double duty.
The muttering stops. The resentment doesn't. Your men obey, but their eyes are cold. Fear keeps order, but it makes enemies of friends.
The Runner

Your night watch caught a soldier trying to slip away with his gear. He stands before you now, shame-faced and trembling.\n\n'Commander, I... I couldn't take it anymore. My nerve broke. Please, I wasn't thinking. I just wanted to go home.'
Desertion is punishable by death. Report to the provost.
The man is dragged away. In the morning, the army's justice is carried out. Your men stand silently. No one else will try to run. But they won't forget what you did.
Ten lashes. Then back to duty. This never happened.
The lashes are administered. The man takes his punishment without a word. He returns to his tent, bloodied but still one of yours. Some think you were merciful. Others think you were cruel.
We've all felt fear. Return to your post. Do not make me regret this mercy.
The man's eyes widen. He nods, returns to his tent. Your officers disapprove, but your soldiers see a commander with a heart. Whether that's wisdom or weakness remains to be seen.
From the Ranks
One of your soldiers has distinguished himself. In the last skirmish, he held a breach single-handed while others fell back. He's earned recognition.\n\nHow do you reward such bravery?
Form up! This man is now corporal. Learn from his example.
The men cheer as you pin the rank on his shoulder. He stands taller. Some are inspired. Others are jealous. Such is the nature of advancement.
Come to my tent. We should talk about your future.
You promote him quietly, explaining your expectations. He accepts with dignity. Word spreads naturally. Those who deserved to know, know.
No rank, but take this purse. You've earned it.
You press coins into his hand. He grins. 'Thank you, Commander.' Sometimes gold speaks louder than titles. He'll remember this generosity.
Fever in Camp

Three of your soldiers are down with fever. They cough and shiver in their tents. The camp surgeon looks grim.\n\n'Could spread, Commander. We should isolate them. But that means stopping to rest while the army marches on.'
Set up a quarantine tent. We'll catch up when they're better.
You set up a sick tent and assign the surgeon to watch them. The army marches ahead. In a week, your men recover. They remember you didn't leave them to die.
They march or they get left behind. We cannot slow down.
You push them hard. Two recover on the road through sheer willpower. The third keeps up through grit and fear.
One collapses on the road. Another infects two more. Soon you have five sick soldiers and a retinue that hates you for your callousness.
Pay for a proper healer. Spare no expense.
You pay for proper medicine and skilled care. Within days, your soldiers recover fully. Word spreads - your commander pays for healing. That means something to men who face death.
One of Your Own

Stay with him until the end
You kneel beside him. Hold his hand. He dies quietly, knowing he wasn't alone. Your men see this. They remember.
Demand the surgeon treat him now
The surgeon scowls but complies. Your man survives, barely. The surgeon won't forget this.
The surgeon tries, but it's too late. Your man dies on the table. The surgeon blames you for wasting his time.
There's nothing you can do. Move on.
You stand and walk away. His eyes follow you until they don't. Your men exchange looks. They understand. They don't like it.
First Command

Your first battle as a commander is over. You led men into the fight. Some followed your orders perfectly. Some hesitated. Some didn't come back.\n\nYou're standing alone now, watching your soldiers tend their wounds. This is what command feels like.
Take a moment. Process what just happened.
You breathe. Think. Remember the mistakes and the successes. Command is weight. You'll carry it better next time.
Rally your men. Show strength.
You walk among them, checking wounds, offering words. They see you as their commander now. Not just a promoted soldier.
Count the losses. Remember the names.
You go through the list. Every man lost, every name. Your soldiers watch you do it. They know you'll remember them too.
The Coward

One of your men ran. You saw it during the fighting—turned and fled while the rest held the line. Now the battle is over and he's back, trying to blend in with the others.\n\nYour sergeant is waiting for your order. The men are watching.
Public flogging. Make an example.
He takes the lashes without a sound. The men watch in silence. They won't run. But they won't love you for this.
Talk to him privately. Find out why.
He breaks down. First battle. Saw his brother die in the last war. You assign him to the rear for now. The men respect that you listened.
He makes excuses. Lies. Your men see weakness in both of you. Should have been harsher.
Remove him from your retinue. Send him back to the main force.
He's reassigned. Your men nod approval. You don't tolerate cowardice, but you're not cruel about it.
Let it go. Everyone has a bad day.
You say nothing. The men exchange glances. If running is acceptable, what else is? Your authority weakens.
Early Looters

The fighting just ended. Bodies are still warm. You find some of your men already rifling through enemy packs, pocketing valuables.\n\nLooting rights haven't been called yet. Technically, this is theft from the army's share. But soldiers have always done this. The question is whether you stop it.
Look the other way. Let them have it.
You turn and walk away. Your men grin and keep working. They'll remember this. So might the officers, if they notice.
Stop them. Order them back to formation.
They grumble but comply. You're following regulations. Your men think you're a stickler. The officers think you're reliable.
Help them. Take a share for yourself.
You kneel down and start searching bodies with them. They laugh. You're one of them now. Command just got more complicated.
The Prisoner's Plea

Your men have captured an enemy officer. He's wounded, disarmed, and begging for his life. Says he has a family. Offers ransom.

One of your soldiers—a veteran—spits at him. "His kind killed my brother. Let me finish him."

Your decision. Your responsibility.
Let your man have his revenge.
Your soldier draws his blade. It's over quickly. The prisoner dies cursing you. Your men nod approval. You've chosen their side.
Take him prisoner. He's worth more alive.
You order him bound and sent to the rear. Your soldier glares at you. The prisoner thanks you. Gold is gold, but this cost you something.
Ask your men to vote. Their call.
You put it to them. They argue. Eventually they vote to spare him for the ransom. Your soldier accepts it, barely. You've shown you trust their judgment.
The vote is swift and brutal. Execute. You've given them power, and they've used it. The prisoner dies. You're complicit.

"Your retinue fought well, Commander. They held the flank when others wavered. I'm pleased."

Your men straighten up, hearing this. How you respond matters.
"Thank you, my lord. We did our duty."
Your lord nods, satisfied. Your men appreciate the humility. You're a commander, but you're not arrogant about it.
"The credit belongs to my men, my lord. They're the ones who bled."
Your men exchange glances. You just gave them the glory. They'll remember this. Your lord smiles slightly—good leadership.
"We held because I trained them well, my lord."
Your lord's smile fades. Your men shift uncomfortably. You just took all the credit. That's not how you build loyalty.

Free at Last
After the next battle.

The battle comes. When it's over, in the chaos of the aftermath, you simply walk away.
No one notices one more body missing from the count.

Free.

Night. A quiet corner of camp. {SOLDIER_NAME} and two others huddle close.

They look at the distant campfires. "When do we go? Tonight? Wait for the next town? After the next battle when everyone's distracted?"
Every option has risks.
When Do We Leave?
{SERGEANT_NAME} nods. "That's the spirit. Keep your head down, do good work. They'll notice." A setback, not a defeat. The path forward is clear, if harder.
"I understand. I'll earn it properly."
The captain hears you out. "Convince me you've changed." You do. Or try to. "Probationary advancement. One incident, and you're back where you started." A chance.
"The decision stands. Prove yourself through action, not words." Appeal denied. You've wasted political capital.
"I want to speak to the captain. Make my case directly."
"Maybe." {SERGEANT_NAME} doesn't argue. "But politics or not, you gave them ammunition. Stop doing that." Cold comfort. True, though.
"Politics. It's always politics."
{SERGEANT_NAME} grabs your shoulder. "None of that. You're a soldier, act like one." Harsh. But sometimes harsh is what you need.
"What's the point? They'll never promote someone like me."

The promotion list goes up. Your name should be on it — the experience, the time served, the battles. But it's not there.
{SERGEANT_NAME} finds you staring at the roster.

Next time. If there is one.
Promotion Blocked
The captain nods. "Then it's done. Turn in your equipment. You're no longer part of this army." It's over. Not with a bang, but with paperwork.
"I have nothing to say. I accept the judgment."
A long silence. "Against my better judgment... penal detail. Six months. Any incident and this offer disappears." A thread of hope. Thin as spider silk.
"We've given you chances. Too many." The captain shakes their head. "Sentence stands."
"Please — one more chance. I'll be different. I swear it."
"Noted." The captain's voice is ice. "Your attitude explains much." The discharge proceeds. No pension. No reference. Nothing.
"Discharge me then. This army never valued me anyway."
The captain reviews documents. Consults with officers. "Your combat record... is not nothing. Reduction in rank. Final warning. Don't make us regret this."
"Service doesn't excuse conduct. Many have served without becoming a disciplinary nightmare." No mercy.
"My service record — the battles, the duties, the blood I've shed for {LORD_NAME}—"

"Dishonorable discharge."
The words hang in the air. The captain doesn't look pleased to say them — or maybe they do. Hard to tell.
"Your record speaks for itself. Consistent failure to meet standards. Repeated infractions despite correction. You've left us no choice."
the company watches from the edge of the assembly. {SERGEANT_NAME}'s face is stone.

Facing Discharge
It's brutal. Every muscle aches. But you don't complain, don't slack. By week's end, the sergeant gives you a curt nod. "Maybe you're learning after all."
Accept the punishment. Do the work.
"Unfair?" The sergeant's voice carries across the camp. "You want to talk about UNFAIR?" The lecture that follows is worse than the extra duty. And you've still got to do the duty.
Protest the unfairness of the punishment.
You throw yourself into every task. Best-dug latrines in the camp. Not a drop of water spilled. The sergeant notices. Grudging respect, maybe. At least you're not a whiner.
Not just do it — do it better than anyone. Make a point.
Turns out, yes. They can. Extended duty. Double shifts. Someone's always watching now. You've made this worse.
Do the minimum. What are they going to do, punish you more?

The duty roster goes up. Your name's on it. Again. And again. And twice more after that.
Extra duty — the army's favorite corrective measure. Latrine digging, night watch, hauling water, whatever's worst. Your infractions have been noticed, and this is the price.
{SERGEANT_NAME} shrugs when you look at them. "Out of my hands. Sergeant's orders."
A week of this, minimum.
Extra Duty
The captain studies you. "Accountability. That's something, at least." The punishment is firm but fair. You've shown character, if not competence.
"No excuses, sir. I failed to meet standards. I accept whatever punishment you decide."
"Interesting." The captain makes notes. "We'll be speaking to these individuals." You've deflected scrutiny. But someone's going to know you named names.
Point fingers. Others share responsibility — maybe more than you.
The captain raises an eyebrow. "Bold. Very well." The confrontation that follows is ugly, but you poke holes in the case. Charges reduced.
"You're in no position to demand anything." The captain's patience is gone. "Charges stand. Punishment enhanced for attitude."
"Some of these charges are exaggerated. I demand to face my accusers."
The captain listens. Nods, occasionally. "Context noted. Punishment will reflect... mitigating factors." You've bought some leniency.
"Excuses. I hear excuses." The captain's voice is cold. "Next."
Lay out the context. The pressures, the circumstances, the reasons behind each incident.

A formal hearing. The captain presides, {LORD_NAME}'s banner hanging behind them. You stand before a table of officers.
"Soldier {PLAYER_NAME}. The charges: repeated failure to maintain discipline standards, disregard for orders, and conduct prejudicial to good order."
They read from a list. Every infraction, every slip-up, documented and damning.
"What do you have to say for yourself?"
The Hearing
{SERGEANT_NAME} nods slowly. "See that it doesn't." The warning's been delivered. Ball's in your court now.
"You're right. I've been slipping. It won't happen again."
{SERGEANT_NAME}'s expression hardens. "There are always circumstances. The question is whether you rise above them." They walk away. Not convinced.
"It's not my fault — there were circumstances—"
A slight softening. "Just... be better. That's all I'm asking." They've stuck their neck out for you. Don't make them regret it.
"Thanks for the heads up. I mean it."
"I don't want to hear it." {SERGEANT_NAME} cuts you off. "Everyone's got complaints. Not everyone makes them the camp's problem." The message is clear: shut up and soldier.
